edu.lehigh.cse.lol

Class Lol

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.lehigh.cse.lol.Lol

  • public class Lol
extends java.lang.Object
    The Lol object is the outermost container for all of the functionality of the game.

    The Lol object implements ApplicationListener, which provides hooks for rendering the game, stopping it, resuming it, and handling any Android lifecycle events.

    In addition to ApplicationListener duties, the Lol object is responsible for providing an abstracted interface to some of the hardware (e.g., the back button and persistent storage), loading resources, and forwarding key/touch inputs to the appropriate handlers.

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors

      Lol(Config config)
      The constructor just creates a media object and calls configureGravity, so that all of our globals will be set.

    • Constructor Detail

      • Lol

        public Lol(Config config)
        The constructor just creates a media object and calls configureGravity, so that all of our globals will be set. Doing it this early lets us access the configuration from within the LWJGL (Desktop) main class. That, in turn, lets us get the screen size correct (see the desktop project's Java file).
        Parameters:
        config - The game-wide configuration

    • Method Detail

      • create

        public void create()
        App creation lifecycle event.

        The lifecycle of LibGDX games splits app startup into two parts. First, an ApplicationListener is constructed. However, it is constructed *very* early, and can't even do all of the things one might expect. For example, it doesn't have an OpenGL context yet, so it can't load its assets from disk. In the second stage, the create method, we can finish constructing the application, knowing that it has access to the full resources of the device.

        NB: This is an internal method for initializing a game. User code should never call this.

      • dispose

        public void dispose()
        App dispose lifecycle event

        When the app is disposed (on terminate or suspend to background), this lets us turn off music and release any resources that won't survive.

        NB: This is an internal method. User code should never call this.

      • render

        public void render()
        This code is called every 1/45th of a second to update the game state and re-draw the screen

        NB: This is an internal method. User code should never call this.

      • pause

        public void pause()
        App lifecycle Pause event. Note that we don't have to do anything special on a pause NB: This is an internal method. User code should never call this.

      • resume

        public void resume()
        App lifecycle Resume event. Note that we don't have to do anything special on a resume NB: This is an internal method. User code should never call this.

      • resize

        public void resize(int width,
                   int height)
        App lifecycle Resize event. Note that we don't have to do anything special on a resize NB: This is an internal method. User code should never call this.
